subject: probability
title: Independence of Events
contentHtml:
In probability theory, two events are considered independent if the occurrence or non-occurrence of one event does not affect the probability of the other event.

Intuitively, this means that knowing the outcome of one event does not change our understanding of the likelihood of the other event. For example, flipping a coin and rolling a die are independent events because the outcome of one does not influence the probability of the other.
name: Independence Formula" },
intuition: Think of it like two separate experiments. If one experiment doesn't affect the outcome of the other, they're independent.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, independence is crucial when combining features or models to avoid spurious correlations.
commonMistakes: Don't confuse independence with disjointness (mutually exclusive events).
